citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
During this inspection, a feral cat was noted near the outside rabbit enclosure. When the facility representative was asked
about the cat and health concerns for the resident animals, she explained the attending veterinarian did have concerns
and recommended something be done about the cats.
When the attending veterinarian was contacted, she confirmed her concerns about the feral cats and the possible
diseases they could transfer to the animals, and she confirmed she had advised something be done to
catch/relocate/prevent feral cats.
Each dealer and exhibitor shall assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of
adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.
Since the veterinarian has recommended something be done about the feral cats and nothing has been done, the
veterinarian has not been given appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care.
The veterinarian’s recommendation that something be done about the feral cats needs to be followed.
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023

During the inspection it was noted there was a large amount of black staining on the carpet in front of the indoor rabbit
enclosure. When asked about the staining, the facility representative explained the roof over the corner of the enclosure
leaks and the stain is a result of the leak. When asked if the black color was mold, the representative said she wasn’t
sure, but possible.
Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to protect the health of the animals and facilitate prescribed husbandry
practices. Allowing the roof to continuously leak and carpet to mold is endangering the health of the animals by
compromising the environment and air they are exposed to.
The roof needs to be repaired and the carpet replaced/cleaned or the rabbits need to be moved to a different location.
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023

• The wood portion of the perimeter fence surrounding the entire facility is in poor repair. Multiple wood slats had
portions missing from either the top or bottom. Whole sections of fence appeared ready to fall. The gate to the back door
wouldn’t close.
The purpose of a perimeter fence is to protect the animals in the facility by restricting unwanted animals and unauthorized
persons from having contact with facility animals. This perimeter fence has failed to restrict unwanted animals and
unauthorized person. The facility has photos of cat food being dumped through holes in the fence for feral cats. This
situation has endangered the resident animals by attracting unwanted feral animals.
The wooden portion of perimeter fence needs to be repaired so that it adequately restricts unwanted animals and
unauthorized persons.
• The wood barrier separating the bobcat enclosure from the public is approximately 6 inches from the primary enclosure.
Barriers must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primarily enclosure to prevent physical contact between
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the enclosure for the safety of the public and the animals.
Fences less than 3 feet from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. This barrier needs to
be relocated to a minimum of 3 feet from the primary enclosure or written approval for the current location needs to be
obtained from the Administrator.
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023

During the inspection, it was noted there was a large amount of black staining on the carpet in front of the indoor squirrel
enclosure. When asked about the staining, the facility representative explained the roof over the corner of the enclosure
leaks and the stain is a result of the leak. When asked if the black color was mold, the representative said she wasn’t
sure, but possible.
Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to protect the health of the animals and facilitate prescribed husbandry
practices. Allowing the roof to continuously leak and carpet to mold is endangering the health of the animals by
compromising the environment and air they are exposed to.
The roof needs to be repaired and the carpet replaced/cleaned or the squirrel needs to be moved to a different location.
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
During this inspection, a feral cat was noted near the outside rabbit enclosure. When the facility representative was asked 
about the cat and health concerns for the resident animals, she explained the attending veterinarian did have concerns 
and recommended something be done about the cats. 
When the attending veterinarian was contacted, she confirmed her concerns about the feral cats and the possible 
diseases they could transfer to the animals, and she confirmed she had advised something be done to 
catch/relocate/prevent feral cats. 
Each dealer and exhibitor shall assure that the attending veterinarian has appropriate authority to ensure the provision of 
adequate veterinary care and to oversee the adequacy of other aspects of animal care and use.  
Since the veterinarian has recommended something be done about the feral cats and nothing has been done, the 
veterinarian has not been given appropriate authority to ensure the provision of adequate veterinary care.  
The veterinarian’s recommendation that something be done about the feral cats needs to be followed. 
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023 
3.56(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
During the inspection it was noted there was a large amount of black staining on the carpet in front of the indoor rabbit 
enclosure. When asked about the staining, the facility representative explained the roof over the corner of the enclosure 
leaks and the stain is a result of the leak. When asked if the black color was mold, the representative said she wasn’t

Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to protect the health of the animals and facilitate prescribed husbandry 
practices. Allowing the roof to continuously leak and carpet to mold is endangering the health of the animals by 
compromising the environment and air they are exposed to. 
The roof needs to be repaired and the carpet replaced/cleaned or the rabbits need to be moved to a different location. 
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023 
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor.

•  The wood portion of the perimeter fence surrounding the entire facility is in poor repair. Multiple wood slats had 
portions missing from either the top or bottom. Whole sections of fence appeared ready to fall. The gate to the back door 
wouldn’t close.  
The purpose of a perimeter fence is to protect the animals in the facility by restricting unwanted animals and unauthorized 
persons from having contact with facility animals. This perimeter fence has failed to restrict unwanted animals and 
unauthorized person. The facility has photos of cat food being dumped through holes in the fence for feral cats. This 
situation has endangered the resident animals by attracting unwanted feral animals. 
The wooden portion of perimeter fence needs to be repaired so that it adequately restricts unwanted animals and 
unauthorized persons. 
• The wood barrier separating the bobcat enclosure from the public is approximately 6 inches from the primary enclosure. 
Barriers must be of sufficient distance from the outside of the primarily enclosure to prevent physical contact between 
animals inside the enclosure and animals or persons outside the enclosure for the safety of the public and the animals. 
Fences less than 3 feet from the primary enclosure must be approved in writing by the Administrator. This barrier needs to 
be relocated to a minimum of 3 feet from the primary enclosure or written approval for the current location needs to be 
obtained from the Administrator. 
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023 
3.131(c) 
   
Sanitation. 
During the inspection, it was noted there was a large amount of black staining on the carpet in front of the indoor squirrel 
enclosure. When asked about the staining, the facility representative explained the roof over the corner of the enclosure 
leaks and the stain is a result of the leak. When asked if the black color was mold, the representative said she wasn’t 
sure, but possible. 
Premises shall be kept clean and in good repair to protect the health of the animals and facilitate prescribed husbandry

compromising the environment and air they are exposed to. 
The roof needs to be repaired and the carpet replaced/cleaned or the squirrel needs to be moved to a different location. 
To be corrected by: July 1, 2023 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
